captions.text: Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday.

So due to tornados and broken airplanes and
a chain of events too complicated for my exhausted

brain to unravel, I have visited airports
9 times in the past 100 hours and I am very

tired, and recently I unexpectedly found myself
alone on a train in New York, the city where

Brotherhood 2.0 began for me, and also the
city where earlier this year we played a sold

out show at Carnegie Hall, a dependent clause
that I will get tired of saying when never.

So anyway, there I was on the train blinking
a lot, because my eyes desperately wanted

to be closed, and I kept thinking about this
tumblr message I had received earlier, from

a middle school student, who is currently
attending the very same school that I attended

in 7th grade, and who has one of the same
teachers that I had.

The message read in part: Ms [name retracted]
and I were talking, and she told me that you

were a quiet, unique and miserable boy in
middle school. She also told me that you were
bullied because of your awesomeness.

It didn't feel like awesomeness at the time
of course, at the time, I was just miserable.

I mean Hank, you'll note that this teacher
didn't say I was a good student, because I

wasn't. I wasn't merely a nerd, I was, or
at least I felt like I was, a stupid nerd,

which is like the worst kind of combo. I take
that back, pizza combos are the worst kind
of combos, they are an insult to pizza.

But anyway, I almost never think about middle
school now Hank, but the message really forced

me to remember it, and also I was on a train,
which inherently makes you kind of nostalgic.

So yeah, it's true that I was miserable, and
that I was bullied. In fact, I would often

fantasise about hurting my bullies, or holding
a gun to their heads and making them apologise,

making them feel as scared and powerless as
I felt. But of course, that isn't the way
forward.

I realise now that the people who bullied
me were not evil, they were kids, living with

their own fear and pain, some of whom were
dealing with trauma and abuse that I never

even could of imagined. Now that doesn't justify
their behaviour, but it does help me to understand

that it really wasn't about me. Their treatment
of me was not a reflection of my value as

a human being, and while it was very difficult
for me to feel anything but miserable in those

days, in retrospect I survived middle school
because many people in fact were quite kind

to me. My parents, teachers, fellow nerds
and even popular strangers who wouldn't stand
for bullying.

We decide collectively what kind of behaviour
is acceptable, and while The Lord of the Flies

would have you believe that like adolescents
always descend into mere cruelty, my experience

of social orders has been much more complicated.
I've found that sometimes, often even, kids

are capable of tremendous kindness and generosity,
in fact that's been the hallmark of the nerdfighter

community for more than seven years now, and
I'm proud to be a nerdfighter in part because

I wish so much that I could have been one
in 7th grade. There are always nerdfighters

in Our Pants (link in the dooblydoo) who
will listen to you if you will also listen
back, and that is truly awesome.

Right so anyway Hank, there was this moment
onstage at Carnegie Hall, during the soundcheck,

when John Darnielle of the Mountain Goats
said into the mic: "this is a message for

sixteen year old me, not only did you survive,
you are playing piano at Carnegie Hall". Now

I'm not going to tell you that like everyone
who has a tough time as a kid ends up at Carnegie

Hall, but the idea that those years have to
be the best of your life is just ridiculous.

So to the young woman who wrote me, to myself,
stranded far from home in an endless string

of airports and train rides, I call up the
great Robert Frost quote: "The only way out

is through". You will get through. I will
get through.

Hank, I will see you, hopefully from Indianapolis,
on Friday.

comments.text:
Kingman Tnarg says: so so beautiful... Um. Do you remenber when fort your birtday we got together and roaned the streets... And anotger day you played the soundtrack you wrote? And our trip to dairy queen or hardees or burger king where the video game place I grew up at spending hundreds of dollars with quarters on pac man and space invaders... I loved it there just as you loved getting foos there too... Different name but same favorite gathering... Love the co-winky-dinks! I played video games and had pizza there, you had your favotitefood there... I felt so close to you. It's such a good feeling... I love you Jas... 😘😙
I just saw your page online letter and I'm so confused. My mom and sisrter have a way of confusing me (they think they are so much better?). I am really so confused. One day they tell me so many lies ablut you, that you are not my daughter and say I'm a fool for believing the 9 to 14 tests i took... ALL PROVING my paternity... Now my sister is pregnant... That may be a clue to me. She hates me when she is pregnant... But my mom it seems is suffering just as your grandmother, from i dont know what its called... Forgetfulness... Brain chmicals turning off... She is so sure of one memory and its wrong... Anyway. My mom and my sister try to steal you from me and make me feel bad fkr using your mom... You understand how your mon used me... So much nicer than how she used you. And then recently I was at my sisters house and she and my mom sere acting as if you guys were best friends... I'm so confused. My parents and brother and sister are abandoning me it seems... Similar to what it sounds like you went through... Family wise... It feels strange our similarities in life...
Ok bottom line, I have heard many different stories from lunatic mom and psycho bixch Jamie... About first you staying in college and mastering aloadof classes no major. Then how you were on your last semester and thinking about marriage and kids and ... And annother story next time... I love you. What are you doing now or soon or for as long as you can? Its wierd, but you and i seem to have so much jn common. I raised you the same way i was brought op... We were left on our own and our loved ones have used us but we tried tocounferact and go under cover... Its same for. Me. You are SO COOL!!!
Ok main questikn as i have talked around... Whats' up? School? Marriage? Library work? Marriage? Him going to school you mom? Friends/enemies Jamie or my mom? Can you please. Me the truth?
I LOVE YOU JASMINE LEA. I love you. Whenever you want to let me in I want to hear from you honey... I love you! 😘
comments.author: Kingman Tnarg

comments.text:
Thank you for posting this. I'm a middle school teacher in Alabama (sadly, 
not at your Alma Mater), and I have some students that are having trouble 
with this too. I do believe that I will share your message with them and 
maybe they can have their nerd fighter selves come out and be proud of it.﻿
comments.author: Kayla Strickland

comments.text:
this is such an important video to me- I feel like it is assumed that at 
every single high school, there are many many bullies and the entire 
experience is bad. I think there is a lot more depth than the stereotypical 
'everyone is bullied'.
as a freshman in high school, this video helps me gain perspective seeing 
as high school, or middle school do not have to be your flying years. your 
flying years will come eventually, the way I see it as long as you keep on 
trying and working hard.﻿
comments.author: Hannah S

comments.text:
I think about your message in this video all the time, it just brings me to 
tears. You mean so much to me and this message means so much to me. I can't 
express to you in the beautifully said words that you used how many times 
this has helped me. But I just want to put it out there that you are so 
right and if I could go back to my middle school me and tell her that the 
kids who called me chubby cakes for all of 5th and 6th grade wouldn't 
matter to me or those who truly love me I would. But I can't, because I 
can't talk to memories. But I can be comforted in the fact that what 
happens in the future will eventually become the past and I will still 
(hopefully) be surrounded by those who love me more than anything. Even if 
they're not the same people.﻿
comments.author: Abbi Vaughan

comments.text:
This was wonderful, thank you for your thoughts John and for sharing your 
story. ﻿
comments.author: Marieliz Pendang

comments.text:
My grades are below average, and kinda disappointing . When people hear 
about how much I struggle in school they all have the same reaction - "oh, 
but you look smart." This is my legacy. A 15 year old one year away from 
gcse's, and no time for recovery. I'm not going to a good sixth form in my 
city, like hills road. If I'm even lucky, I'm going to get into long road 
and be subjegated to a lifetime of freaking ridicule. I want to act and 
write, and at the same time, I want to do absolutely nothing. Years of 
bullying and depression have just beaten my self worth to a pulp. I have 
not the means or the money to be able to be stupid or talentless without it 
meaning there is nothing for me out there. But here I am, stupid AND 
talentess. All I need is a chance or recognition and it's nearly too late. ﻿
comments.author: midnightsunrose

comments.text: My gosh this made me cry ﻿

comments.author: Crystal Smith

comments.text:
"People were mean to you, but I always thought you were cool..."

Watching the Carnegie Hall video of the Mountain Goats performing that 
song, and also this video, brought back powerful memories of that time of 
may-I-say ridiculously over-rated importance. I *feel* the messages behind 
these videos, and I am vastly thankful for people who talk about it after 
living it.

I am about to graduate with a B.S. in mathematics, am living with my 
fiance, have the privilege of continuing on to my Masters degree and 
hopefully my Ph.D. after that, have plans to start a family in the 
not-so-distant future. I am ABSOLUTELY IN LOVE WITH MY LIFE -- and I know 
that in middle school and even high school I never would have imagined 
finding such a beautiful place in the world as where I am, among people who 
love me and whom I love.

I watch these videos and wish I had been able to see them years ago, but 
also I am so so glad that kids - and people - who are battling that 
situation now might find videos like this and understand that it is not 
about them, that they may never know why people do/say the things they do, 
but that they will get through it...

Really I just wanted to say thanks.

Thanks. DFTBA.
-Jasmine﻿
comments.author: Jasmine Lea

so I'm not sure which this presentation would fit better into.  LOVE YOU 
GUYS!﻿

comments.author: Caitlin Edwards

comments.text:
I was never bullied, per say, in middle school. However, middle school is 
when I remember how scared I was about coming out as a transexual. Other 
kids seemed to despise other people who were "that way," and I felt alone 
and depressed.

Enough about me. What I really want to say is that anyone who is in the 
same situation as mine was, please, don't be scared about telling others 
who you are. Whoever you may happen to be, you are always beautiful in my 
eyes.﻿

comments.author: RebeccaAwesome

comments.text:
Mr. Green, 
 Thank you. You have sincerely and wholeheartedly changed my life for the 
better. For a while last year and the beginning of this year, I suffered 
from depression. For a while I was self-harming and I wasn't in a good 
mental space. I was scrolling though youtube looking for videos that might 
help me feel better, when your video on Middle School Misery popped up. 
Now, I, like you stated in this video, was bullied constantly. I was forced 
to eat alone at lunch and someone actually carved 'jamie is a lesbian 
hooker' into my desk at school. (lets move onto the happy stuff). What you 
said about how 'everyone telling you that it does get better, you don't 
want to believe it because it isn't getting better the moment you are 
living it' is incredibly true. You made me understand that all these people 
around me were doing what was best for me, I was just too ignorant to see 
it.  Watching you and Hank every Tuesday and Friday were the best moments 
of my week. One night when I was particularly upset, I watched your Esther 
day. It gave to the strength to tell my parent what was happening at 
school. They allowed me to switch school, leaving me the happiest I have 
ever been. (You probably aren't that interested in my personal life so here 
is the over-all: you kept me alive and I can not thank you enough for 
that.)﻿
comments.author: jamie lenehan

comments.text:
This post is beautiful. Not only like what he's saying but also... The 
video. The actual graphic content of this really made me think. Of course 
john green is no stranger to me and if I saw him on the train I would die 
but a lot of nerdfighters and just... People are. We all ride the trains 
and buses and have thoughts of our own. In john's video he is just another 
passerby, he is a face, and a freak at that. A man on a train taping 
himself silently. We would all walk past some one like him and I bet I do 
walk past people as brilliant as himself every day. It made me think a lot 
and I suppose that's what this all is nerdfighteria and all. DFTBA. ﻿

comments.text:
Just found this video and this was definetely what I needed. I went through 
similar experiences during elementary and middle school. I used to have the 
same thoughts as John used to have... Even now, 6 years later, I still look 
back, thinking " I could have done this.".. or " I should have done that 
that time" . I come from a place being a "pussy" (excuse my language) is 
looked down at and that being shy or quiet is somehow associated with it. 
It sucks. 

I guess whenever I have these thoughts, I will have a look at this video... 
And think otherwise. Thanks for sharing...﻿

comments.author: Ayde Flores

comments.text:
The idea that a kid could think of pointing a gun to another kid, no matter 
how mean they are, just brings me the chills and makes me nauseous. I don't 
if it is because I had a pretty sheltered childhood in a country where guns 
were owned only by cops, really mean robbers and a few people that hunted, 
or because I think guns are one of the most vile objects in existence and 
I'm petrified of them, but I simply cannot wrap my head around the fact 
that there is little gun control in America, and that people can talk about 
them in such a liberal manner. Just watching John adressing his pre-teen 
thoughts (maybe even fantasies), which involve guns, in such a calm manner 
doesn't sit right by me. I don't know if I'm alone in this, but I had to 
get my opinion out. Have a nice day.﻿
comments.author: Celi Méndez

comments.text: Well, we'll just have to agree to disagree.
comments.author: Celi Méndez

comments.text:
Guns are a tool, nothing more. The simple fact that they exist means that 
bad people will have them, and they are easy to come by. It is best if the 
good human beings own guns as well, so order can be kept. Example, gun 
control has worked out great in Mexico. *Sarcasm*

Also many people occasionally fantasize about killing people they despise, 
especially those who are frequently tormented, but most are perfectly sane. 
Power fantasies can be stress relievers.
comments.author: Cole Kinghorn

comments.text:
I understand what you mean - I've grown up in America, and the stuff that 
comes out of it regarding gun control is pretty screwed up. But as for the 
fantasy/thoughts relating to violence against bullies . . . it's actually 
pretty common if you're bullied a lot. Not specifically with the guns, but 
it happens. I know in my case, the point in which I start thinking of 
aggression against bullies is the point where I need to call in some help. 
So you are right, it's heinous. But it happens often, sadly.

comments.text:
There wasn't a moment of my formal education I didn't hate. When I was 
really young I was taunted relentlessly for everything, so when I got to 
high school I mostly became a ghost apart from when I could do something 
smart or music-y. It's bull shit that high school is the best years of your 
life, you don't have to enjoy it, you just have to get through it which is 
not a useful thing to hear but is probably the most true. The only thing 
that kept me going through the worse parts of my high school experience was 
the idea that if I just stopped then I was never going to get out of my 
crappy town and that terrified me more than whatever anyone else could do 
to me﻿

comments.text:
I'm in my A-level years and bullying has never been a problem with me, but 
I always felt sort of invisible. Everyone still likes to pretend I'm not 
there. I realised that at the end of year 8 when we were moving up to high 
school and every kid had to write something nice about all the others, they 
didn't repeat duplicates when they handed you the page of all the things 
that had been said about you. I had two things "nice voice" and "smart". 
That was it. ﻿

the Ball Tag the Queer system. I don't know what to do about it but I don't 
like. I just had a crying fit.

comments.text:
Yeah. I went trough this period until 4th grade. I was also there in early 
6th grade. In between that time I was bullied. I am a huge nerd. Later (in 
that mid-sixth grade era) I decided I was fed up with the popular kids, the 
ones who were horrible to me. I started a nerd revolution of sorts that 
made kids like me feel strong and more equal. The kids who bullied me will 
always be my enemies, but the other boys now support my ideas and i became 
the "popular kid". It's the best and weirdest thing ever.

comments.author: GUAXIMAN

comments.text:
How old is middle school? I'm currently a secondary school student in 
England, which is ages 11-18. I spent most of the ages 7-13 absolutely 
miserable due to bullying, but there's one specific incident that comes to 
mind. I came out as bisexual to everyone (not by choice) when I was 11, and 
one day two girls followed me home, shouting all kinds of homophobic crap 
at me. Then, suddenly, it stopped, and when I turned around to see if it 
was safe to run away, I saw an old man telling them off. Thank you, random 
man. They never followed me again.﻿
comments.author: Sally McSaggytits

comments.text:
I treat it 7-9 grade, but that is probably because I am in Canada. How did 
you say to people that you are bisexual, as that would be a huge surprise 
to many, and depending on when this was, it may have been more socially 
acceptable closer to now than when John was a middle schooler. I feel very 
lucky to not have actually been bullied in school. Sure some people did 
sometimes make a joke now and again, but it was never like I lived in 
terror of bullies. What does **come out** even mean BTW, it feels to me 
like it suggests that people are saying they broke out of jail or an egg, 
like a chick does (think chickens not females). That is what it intuitively 
means to me, but now with it being used to describe if you announce that 
you are not heterosexual.
comments.author: restlesswikiinfo

comments.author: C Pinney

comments.text:
Middle school is a school between elemantary school and high school. Some 
schools like my middle school is grades 6-8. But other schools like my moms 
is 6-9 and I agree with you about bullying. I have been bullied a few times 
but not recently the last time I got bullied was the fourth grade. I know a 
kid who is a senior in high school and they are gay and transgender. (I 
don't know what pronouns they are currently using so I'm gonna use they and 
them). I remember a good friend of mine saying that they got bullied which 
is a shame because they are really nice. We did color guard together 
(Colorguard if you don't know is an activity where a team will perform with 
flags, rifles, and sabres,) and we were at a football game they started 
talking about doing estrogen therapy. I decided then and there that if they 
had strength to be openly gay/trans then I shouldn't be afraid to be openly 
bisexual. I came out at my first football game. (Sorry for making this 
story about me) sometimes bullying can lead to the most tragic things 
(suicide, school shootings) but it can also lead to stronger and better 
people. I'm not exusing bullying it's a horrible thing. But thats my two 
sense and I hope my explanation helped.

comments.author: Kermicheo Kermit

comments.text:
My School does"bulling lessons" for a day during the first week of school 
every year,  they are basically a set of lessons that try to explain, 
define, and prepare you for, bullying. They are perfectly acceptable for 
anyone who hasn't been bullied, but those who have, recognize the amount of 
baloney that they are. Im not going to get into the number of reasons why, 
just the point that this was a convenient time to re-watch this because the 
lessons were this week and it has been on and off of my mind since. Im a 
Senior in High School now, but on and off until 10th grade I was bullied, 
some grades it was pretty bad, I spent most of 5th grade hiding from my 
peers in the bathroom, reading. Im glad to have grown from it though, and 
gained experience, because I also met one of the best friends I could ever 
have, because she defended me.  During the second set of lessons a girl a 
couple seats in front of me decided to share her voice that the Victims, 
"just need to suck it up", and even that "Its their choice to be bullied" 
Because they don't avoid it or change or defend or whatever. We ended up 
(peacefully) going back and forth for a while. One of the points later 
brought up was "Why is it any of our business" and I realized how much 
nerdfighteria has influenced me. Its our business because we are a society 
of human beings, it is our job as a society. Because our conscience  is one 
of the things that separate us as humans. Because no one deserves to hate 
themselves, and no on deserves to feel like their only way to gain 
"respect" is the cruel ways the bully's gain it. This didn't exist then, 
but I wish I could send this video to 5th and 9th grade me. The words seem 
to live on forever, even after you realize the reality of them.﻿
comments.author: Vicky Hallam

I'm so glad I went to the schools I did.  My grade school was K-8, so the 
whole middle school experience was very similar to grade school (we had 
recess up through eighth grade, which was awesome), and it was really 
small, only about sixty kids attended, so I think the teachers had a lot 
better handle of what was going on there than at a public school.  I think 
it was also reassuring when everything else was changing with my body and 
my emotions to be in the same place.﻿

comments.text:
I would quit my job on the day that I showed up and got physically 
assaulted by a a co-worker, and no one would second-guess my decision.  But 
I wasn't allowed to quit going to school alongside plenty of kids who had 
assaulted me.  Grown-ups should be ashamed that we haven't fixed schools. 
 If my kid is ever assaulted in school, I'll hold the attacker's parents 
responsible, because my child won't grow up thinking they deserved it, or 
it was their fault, or they could have avoided it by "ignoring the bullies"﻿

comments.author: Ymani Ethridge

comments.text:
To the middle schooler (or high schooler) bullied or made to feel like 
nothing:
As a high school freshman, I can say that middle school SUCKS. And high 
school isn't all it cracked up to be. I was bullied in middle school. I 
don't have many friends (I can count them on one hand). Most of my other 
classmates aren't really bullying me but are all doing little things that 
build up and make me feel like I am worth nothing. I am not worth nothing. 
And neither are you. Talk to someone. Your mother, father, or any family 
member. Or one of your friends. Or the school counselor. Or maybe some 
stranger you trust or have something in common with on the Internet. 
Someone. Anyone. Talking may be hard, but it helps. It really does (See? 
I'm doing it now and it is helping me). I got into fights in middle school, 
and trust me, you do not want that. Find a group of kids in school that you 
can relate to. No matter how small. Find a way to relieve stress (just as 
long as bullying others or fighting isn't involved). Whatever you do, don't 
think that now is the best time of your life. You have 60 or more years 
ahead of you. Embrace those years. Life is too long for you to think you 
will amount to nothing.﻿
